questions.questionDescription: I like to learn things just for the benefit of learning.
I prefer to be spontaneous rather than plan a lot.
Some people make mistakes. but I try not to get involved because it's not my responsibility.
Supervisors need to keep tight controls over employees to make sure that work is done correctly.
I tend to be suspicious when someone I don't know tries to help me.
A good supervisor must be very careful not to interfere with the work of his/her subordinates, otherwise s/he can lose their support.
I usually like to do things the existing way instead of trying new ways.
If you really want something done right, you need to do it yourself.
Working with others can be very frustrating.
Managers who give too much responsibility to their employees will eventually become unnecessary for the company.
If I was a supervisor and had new employees, I'd prefer to let them find out for themselves about the rules and regulations of the company.
I always know the right answer.
I prefer to plan my days in advance and then follow my schedule.
If I see someone doing something incorrectly at work, I need to help him/her do it right.
It is important that a manager takes time to talk to his/her employees about non-work related topics.
I've never enjoyed team activities.
I prefer jobs that allow me to learn new things.
If I found out that one of my subordinates was not working properly, I would wait until he/she does it better instead of talking with them immediately.
A small group of people usually can come up with better ideas than one person by him/herself.
I try hard to keep my work area organized.
Planning ahead helps me to deal with problems when they come up.
I work better with others than I do alone.
I look forward to the challenges of the day.
I prefer individual sports to team sports.
Talking to employees about personal problems is something that isn't appropriate for a manager.
It would be diffcult to live with a messy person.
Having a schedule allows me to make the best use of my time.
I feel best when I belong to a group.
I keep my work area clean.
I try to arrive promptly for scheduled activities.
Deep down, most employees don't really want to be involved in decision making.
I would get involved if I saw two coworkers yelling at each other.
I like to feel like I am a member of a team.
I tend to be sensitive to the needs of others.
I you don't keep a watchful eye on your employees, you're bound to have problems.
I like to try out new ideas that I have.
On most projects I have, I try to plan ahead before getting started.
People should be expected to help coworkers who have fallen behind in their work.
Most people are not willing to take responsibility for their actions.
If I was a supervisor and found out that one of my employees wasn't working hard, I would give them some time to improve before saying anything.
I enjoy working with other as part of a team.
I do not like to set up and follow a schedule.
I enjoy helping out to get the job done.
People would describe me as a cautious person.
I have a hard time going along with the group unless the group uses my ideas or suggestions.
When I delegate a project to someone, I make sure s/he understands clearly what s/he needs to do.
I'd rather work as part of a group than by myself.
Only the top 10% of employees can be trusted with additional responsibility.
The threat of being fired for bad performance is a powerful motivator for most employees.
Even if something is working well, I think about how it can be improved.
It's all right to delegate fact-finding to employees, but managers need to make all of the final decisions.
If I were a manager and an employee decreased his/her performance, I would speak with that employee as soon as possible and try to understand what is causing it.
If I were a supervisor, I would make sure to thank my employees when they did a job well.
